subject: Re: Utter/Ado
msgSnippet: ... Yes, the first pass at a rule for this is a little weak. Still, it may yet be rescue-able with a little invention. ... QS spelling must be fully
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
> Anthony Grahn scripsit:
>>
>> Do not use the letter Utter for COMMA. Indeed do not have any letter
>> represent the indefinite vowel. Instead write the letter for the
>> sound the vowel has when it is stressed in that same root.
>
>Except, of course, that some roots have unstressed syllables to which the
>stress never shifts.
>...
>

Yes, the first pass at a rule for this is a little weak. Still, it may
yet be rescue-able with a little invention.


>
>... No, if we go this route, we are
> truly doing TO with funny-looking symbols.
> ...
>

QS spelling must be fully determinate for utterances. But I don't see
why it must only be the phonemes that are used to determine spelling;
stress too might be valid. At one point, Read himself uses stress to
describe the use of #26It


>> Thus: make Roe cover /r/ *and* the lexical set NURSE (which implies
/3/ )
>
>I like this, except of course that it's explicitly un-Read. While we are
>at it, we could similarly ditch Utter in words like "bottle", "bottom",
>"button"; it adds nothing.
>

It is indeed contrary to the QM just as using Ing for all It+Ing and
Eat+Ing and Ing+Gay combinations is.

But in this case we do derive a very real benefit. The assigning of
NURSE to the letter pair Utter+Roe is causing tangle problems. As it
stands the letter pair Utter+Roe now has two separate sounds. It is
simpler to instead have a single letter with two separate sounds. In
this case Roe is a fair candidate especially since the sounds in
question [3] and [r\] are already pretty closely associated in peoples
minds. Thus while contrary to the QM, the benefit is comparable to the
It/Eat + Ing simplification.
